The Logrus philosophy of Gaelic Learning

Children learn their language by hearing it over and over, observing the context in which words are used, and inferring word meanings and the logic of the language from their exposure to it – with no distraction from hearing a different language. This is “immersion” in the language. It's extolled as the most effective language-learning method, and we've nearly all experienced success with it -- with our native language. It makes sense that we will be successful using the same method to acquire our heritage language. And so the myth is born nothing is required to achieve fluency but immersion.

As adults, however, we face additional challenges. We have lost the “language plasticity” that is natural to young children. We have jobs and social commitments that require us to switch back to our dominant language. Few of us have access to an exclusively Gaelic-speaking community, or to any Gaelic-speaking community for that matter. And so the competing myth is born that it is impossible for an adult to achieve true fluency.

Truth lies somewhere in between.

As adult learners, we have the advantage of understanding many of the basic building blocks of language. We know about nouns and verbs, tenses and conjugation. We may have studied French or Japanese and know that different languages have different word-order and different ways of changing words to express context. Gaelic has these distinctions too, so learning by studying grammar builds on existing understanding. We already understand the value of vocabulary and have practice expressing complex ideas, so we understand the value of memorizing vocabulary lists. And in this age of the internet, .mp3 files, and ear-buds we can ALSO use immersion.

The best way to learn Gaelic is whatever way works. Different techniques will build different strengths, and will work in different circumstances. There's no reason to restrict yourself to just one technique. Try everything, and keep up the strategies that work for you.

Some general advice does apply to all strategies:

  • Learning depends on repetition, repetition, repetition. Whether you favour flashcards or podcasts, you'll need to go through them over and over. Relax, enjoy it, and persist. Repetition is more important than “moving on”.

  • Lose your dignity. Studies show that children do NOT in fact learn foreign languages to fluency without formal teaching. What children have going for them is that they are not yet self-conscious about making mistakes, or appearing to be non-fluent through halting or stumbling speech. Fluency itself is a myth. It does not matter whether you are fluent, or know the right words. What matters is that you try to say SOMETHING. If Syrian refugees who have lost everything and landed in our hospitable-but-frozen homeland can find the courage to go grocery-shopping in English only within a month of arriving, we can surely manage to stammer out a halting sentence or two every time we meet a fellow Gaelic learner, even if we have to supplement our attempts with pantomime and dictionary look-ups. No Judgement! as long as you try.

  • Many language-acquisition experts recommend avoiding translation.Flashcards create associations in your mind. If you put an English word the back of the card, and a Gaelic word on the front, you'll associate the two words. You'll see an apple, think “Apple”, and associate it with “Uhl”. If you put a picture of the apple on the back of the card instead of the English word, your mind will build a direct association between the actual object and “Uhl”. Most flash-card apps will allow you to use pictures.
